chapter.title: Advanced topics
chapter.subtitle: Building and running &C2; from source code
chapter.para: This chapter discusses more advanced usage scenarios of &C2; such as integration with Apache Solr, running &C2; applications in Eclipse and building &C2; from source code.

section.title: Integration with Apache Solr
section.para: As of version 1.4 of Apache Solr, &C2; clustering can be performed directly within Solr. Please see the &C2; Clustering Component wiki page for information on configuring and running &C2;-based search results clustering in Solr.

The 1.4.x line of Apache Solr ships with version 3.1.0 of &C2; clustering algorithms. If you would like to take advantage of the newer releases of &C2; algorithms, you need to apply a compatibility package as shown below.
To upgrade &C2; algorithms in Solr 1.4.x to the newest version:

listitem.para: Remove the following files from your Solr 1.4.x installation:
Copy the contents of the downloaded archive over the Solr home directory.
Start Solr, clustering should be performed by the updated Carrot2 algorithms.

note.para: Solr nightly builds (trunk, branch_3x) already ship with the newest version of &C2; and do not require the compatibility package.

section.title: Running &DCW; in Eclipse IDE
section.para: To run &DCW; in Eclipse IDE (version 3.4 or higher required):

para.link: Set up &C2; source code in your Eclipse IDE.

listitem.para: Choose Window > Preferences and then Run/Debug > String substitution. Add a temp_workspaces variable pointing to a an existing disk directory where the Workbench's workspace should be created.
Choose Run > Run Configurations... from the main menu and run the Workbench configuration.

para.link: Set up &C2; source code in your Eclipse IDE.

listitem.para: Choose Run > External Tools > External Tools Configurations... from the main menu and run the Attribute Metadata XML configuration. This will build the metadata files required for the web application to show advanced options of document sources.

Choose Run > External Tools > External Tools Configurations... from the main menu and run the Web Application Setup [carrot2] configuration. This will preprocess various configuration files required by the web application.
Choose Run > Run Configurations... from the main menu and run the Web Application Runner [carrot2] configuration.
Point your browser to http://localhost:8080 to access the running web application.

section.title: Building &C2; from source code
section.para: To build &C2; applications from source code, you will need Java Softwade Development Kit (Java SDK) version 1.6 or higher and Apache Ant version 1.7.1 or higher. You can chcek out the latest &C2; source code from the following SVN location:

listitem.para: Download Eclipse Target Platform from and extract to some local folder.

Copy workbench.properties.example from &C2; checkout folder to workbench.properties in the same folder. In workbench.properties edit the target.platform property to point to the Eclipse Target Platform you have downloaded.

important.para: The folder pointed to by target.platform must have the eclipse/ folder inside.

listitem.para: You may also need to change the configs property to match the platform you want to build &DCW; for.

Run:
ant -f build-workbench.xml build
to build &DCW; binaries.
Go to the tmp/ workbench/ tmp/ carrot2-workbench folder in the &C2; checkout dir and run &DCW;.

Run:
ant webapp
in the main &PROD; checkout directory.
Go to the tmp/webapp/ folder in the &C2; checkout dir where you will find the web application WAR file.

section.para: Two sources that currently do not support the above properties are: BingDocumentSource and OpenSearchDocumentSource.

note.para: Password-based authentication is not supported at the moment. You can alter the source code to change this in the HttpUtils class.

section.title: Enabling native matrix computations
section.para: To speed up clustering performed by the Lingo algorithm, you can configure &C2; to use a native platform-specific matrix computation library. Depending on the platform, you may see up to a 400% speed-up compared to the Java-only mode.
To enable native matrix computations for &C2;:

listitem.para: Download precompiled libraries for your platform and extract the archive to some local directory.

note.para: If no distribution matches your platform, and you would like to compile your own version, please ask on the mailing list for instructions. You can also try the PIII (Pentium III) versions, which seem to work quite well on modern processors as well (e.g. Core2 Duo).
